channel.title: BBC News - World

item.title: Who is Alina Kabaeva, Putin's alleged girlfriend?
item.description: The EU is proposing to sanction Alina Kabaeva, an ex-gymnast turned media boss close to President Vladimir Putin.

item.title: Belarus Ryanair plane arrest student Sofia Sapega jailed for six years
item.description: The verdict on Sofia Sapega comes a year after she was forcibly removed from a diverted Ryanair flight.

item.title: Facebook accused of deliberately disrupting Australia emergency services
item.description: A whistleblower group claims Facebook allowed a news ban affect vital services to gain leverage.

item.title: Kenyan Muslim cleric refuses to leave jail after acquittal
item.description: He fears being killed by Kenyan state agents as is alleged has happened to other terror suspects.

item.title: Shooting on Dutch care farm leaves two dead
item.description: The victims were a girl of 16 and a 38-year-old woman and a man has been arrested.

item.title: Israel hunts Palestinian axe attackers who killed three
item.description: Three Israelis were killed as two Palestinians bludgeoned civilians in a park full of families.

item.title: Amazon targets review firms with legal action
item.description: The tech giant has accused four companies of flooding its shopping sites with fake reviews.

item.title: US job creation beats forecasts despite headwinds
item.description: Employers added 428,000 jobs last month, while the jobless rate held steady at 3.6%.

item.title: Cocaine found in coffee sent to Nespresso plant
item.description: Swiss police seized 500kg of the drug after workers found white powder in a shipment of coffee beans.

item.title: Ex-officer jailed after rough arrest of woman with dementia
item.description: Austin Hopp has been sentenced to five years for assault after arrest of a woman with dementia.

item.title: Gucci stores to accept cryptocurrencies in US
item.description: Gucci joins a growing number of major companies that have started to accept digital currencies.

item.title: Heatwave: India's poor bear the brunt of blistering temperatures
item.description: As temperatures soar, the country's poorest are struggling to make ends meet and survive the heat.

item.title: Why 9 May Victory Day is so important for Russia
item.description: Vladimir Putin has made it an annual event, but amid war in Ukraine 9 May has taken on new significance.

item.title: Does US really have world's highest Covid death toll?
item.description: A new report suggests other countries had more excess deaths than US during the pandemic.

item.title: Why one firm is banking on carbon fibre bikes in Europe
item.description: Europe's bike firms want to source more components closer to home, including carbon fibre frames.

item.title: Africa's week in pictures: 29 April-5 May 2022
item.description: A selection of the best photos from across Africa this week.

item.title: 'There's power in names': Antigua unearths lost ancestors
item.description: A landmark genealogy project is unearthing the names of enslaved people whose stories were erased.

item.title: Sri Lanka's energy crisis hits country's fishing industry
item.description: A lack of fuel, ice, and places to sell their catch has left fishermen in Jaffna in the lurch.

item.title: Eurovision: Australia's Sheldon Riley's song details his autistic experience
item.description: Australia's contestant Sheldon Riley will compete in Turin with his powerful song Not The Same.

item.title: The volunteer pilots from Germany delivering medical supplies to Ukraine
item.description: The pilots from Germany are flying medical supplies to the Ukraine-Poland border and helping refugees.

item.title: Russia rehearses World War Two victory parade
item.description: Military vehicles, weapons and soldiers were on display at a rehearsal for Russia's Victory Day parade.

item.title: Dust storm and wildfires seen from space
item.description: Satellite images show gusts of up to 60mph blowing dust across Colorado and plumes of smoke in New Mexico.
